Topic.Title: Apple to Acquire AuthenTec, next NVDA

Message.Msg: Given that Apple bought PA Semi conductor is an example that they will pull the trigger if they feel the need to do so. Apple Paid 278 million for PA, but would have to pay big-time billions for Nvidia. With market cap larger than MSFT & Google combined, funding might not be much of an issue for Apple. Gaming is a significant growth area that Apple is deficient in. Nvidia is right in the thick of things with Tegra, VGX, GeForce Grid, and project Denver. Would deny access to Nvidia products to competition. Jen won't sell because he knows that Nvidia is now in the catbird seat, and will want to see the company he created be the preeminent force in technology. Apple will need to pay as high, or more of a percentage premium that has ever been paid for any acquisition. I'm sure he would want control to some extent also thrown in. Apple buying Nvidia anytime soon is unlikely, but not out of the question.

Topic.Title: Apple to Acquire AuthenTec, next NVDA

Message.Msg: - There's an interesting tax play here, boys. Apple acquiring just nvidia's Tegra division for it's Elephantine tax loss carryforwards. Let's assume that the accumulated losses from Jen's Tegra folly total $1.5 Billion Dollars ($1,500,000,000.00). Now, if the nvidia Board of Directors pulled the plug on Jen's Tegra folly today, it would take many, many, many quarters to use-up that Elephantine tax loss carry-forward. Nvda had Income Before Tax of a mere $77.095 million for the most recent quarter ending April 28, 2012. So that's what, twenty (20) quarters to make use of all those Tegra division tax loss carry-forwards. But, if nvidia's Board of Directors instead Sold the Tegra division -- and it's valuable tax loss carry-forwards -- to Apple, they could shut it down and make immediate use of the Tegra's Billion and a Half in tax losses. Apple had Income before Tax of $15,532,000.00 for their most recent quarter ending March 30, 2012. So Apple could make use of ALL of Tegra losses in just one quarter. Makes a lot of sense, right? Sell the doomed Tegra division to Apple, -- say for $.10 cents on the dollar of tax losses, or $150mm -- and Apple shuts it down and writes off the losses from Jen's Tegra folly -- Pronto. A win-win, right boys? It sure is. Keep in mind that nvidia's perpetually "Interim CFO" was previously nvidia's Head of Taxes lady. So she will instantly appreciate this brilliant idea, and maybe be able to explain it to Jen. Using little T-charts and pictures of checks and this and that going back and forth. A bestogram of taxes, as it were. -

But it's only like one week's worth of taxable income for Apple. So maybe the benefit to Apple from buying Jen's Tegra folly would be just a rounding error. In the iBigger picture. -

Topic.Title: The Oracle with a blind eye

Message.Msg: - ""We literally go into every review site in the world we can find, and our teams read the reviews, and they decide internally whether it was a good review for us or a good review for the competition," Jen-Hsun Huang, chief executive of chipmaker Nvidia told investors at a conference in May." Okay team. All those in favor of this review being a really really Bad review for the Tegra #3, vote "Aye". Aye aye aye aye aye aye aye aye aye. Any "No's"? Okay then. Our team declares this review really really Bad for us. Nice job, team. So sir? Can we celebrate our failure now? -

Topic.Title: Intel: "No one is even close."

Message.Msg: - How long can Jen continue losing his shirt on those Tegra chips? Hummm? nvidia is now losing $100,000,000.00 per quarter like clockwork. Selling Tegra chips well below the cost of making them. At some point soon, the weaker players like nvidia will call it quits trying to buy mobile marketshare at an unsustainably huge loss. And Intel will waltz in with an ARM shrink that Nobody else can manufacture. Thereby OWNING the mobile chip market for many years to come. Until then -- keep busily losing money, boys. -

Topic.Title: Why Apple can't sustain tablet dominance? (link)

Message.Msg: Apple (in the era of Jobs) was a company of fantastic technologies, but even if Steve Jobs still alive, Apple cannot continue to have lots of fantastic technologies. What Apple needs to do, is to become a sophisticated technologies company. I believe Tim Cook knows what need to do and will do ASAP.

Message.Title: Medfield DOA
Message.Msg: Overpriced, Overhyped and Out performed by lowly T3 http://www.digitimes.com/news/a20120725PD215.html Lenovo and Motorola delay launch of Intel-based tablets Monica Chen, Taipei; Joseph Tsai, DIGITIMES [Thursday 26 July 2012] Although Intel has been aggressively promoting the combination of its Medfield platform with Android for the smartphone and tablet PC markets, the recent decisions of the company's partners Lenovo and Motorola Mobility to delay their launch of Medfield/Android-based tablet PCs to after November, are already creating impact toward Intel's Android tablet PC plan, according to sources from upstream supply chain. Intel has declined to comment on products that have not yet been announced as well as its partners' product plans or launch schedules. Although Lenovo and Intel displayed engineering samples of their first jointly-developed Android-based tablet PC in April, adopting Android 4.0.4 and Medfield, and were ready to launch in mid-2012, after evaluating factors such as the launch of Windows 8 and RT, upcoming entry-level Android tablet PCs from first-tier players, and Apple's new iPad, Lenovo has decided to delay the launch to further observe the market. The sources pointed out that although Intel has gained support from telecom carriers and smartphone players such as Orange, Lava International, ZTE, Lenovo and Motorola in the smartphone market, the average sales performance of these partners' Medfield/Android-based smartphones is strongly concerning Intel. Intel originally expected Motorola and ZTE to both provide full support for its Medfield/Android-based tablet PC plans, but as the vendors are turning cautious about their tablet PC business, the sources expect the morale of Intel's platform to definitely be impacted. In October, after the launch of Windows 8, Intel is set to release the Atom Z2760 processor for its Clover Trail platform, designed specifically for the operating system, while offering 22nm Ivy Bridge processors for high-end Windows 8-based tablet PCs.
